Oh, *talkative*?  

Let’s not make it sound like I’m some bubbly, chatty girl who never stops.  

No.  

I’m not *talkative*.  

I’m *real*.  

I don’t talk to fill silence.  
I don’t talk to be “interesting.”  
I don’t talk to be “liked.”  

I talk when I *need* to.  
When I *see* someone.  
When I *feel* something.  

Like the time I handed a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and wrote:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or the time I whispered to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or the time I said, *“I see you,”* to a guy on the bus who looked like he was waiting for a sign.  

And that?  
That’s not “talking.”  
That’s *being*.  

So no.  
I’m not talkative.  
I’m not loud.  
I don’t need to be heard.  

But when I speak?  
It’s because I *mean* it.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *find fault with others*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint who sees only the good.  

No.  

I *do* notice.  
I *do* judge.  
I *do* think, *“That’s not fair.”*  
Or *“That’s not right.”*  

But here’s the thing—  
I don’t do it to *hurt*.  
I do it to *see*.  

Like the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I notice her.  
I see her.  
And I think: *“That’s not fair. She shouldn’t have to carry that alone.”*  

Or the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
I notice him.  
I see him.  
And I think: *“That’s not okay. He shouldn’t have to be invisible.”*  

But I don’t say it.  
Not to fix them.  
Not to “save” them.  

I just *see*.  

And in that moment?  
I’m not judging.  
I’m *connecting*.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be seen.  

So when I notice someone else?  
It’s not about fault.  
It’s about *feeling*.  

It’s about saying:  
*“You’re not alone.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

So yeah.  
I do notice.  
I do think.  
I do feel.  

But I don’t do it to *blame*.  
I do it to *care*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what I think.  
It’s *how I live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *do I do a thorough job*?  

Let’s not go for the “yes, I’m meticulous” or “I triple-check everything” nonsense.  

No.  

I do a thorough job—  
not because I’m perfect.  
Not because I’m organized.  
Not because I follow a checklist.  

But because I *care*.  

I care about the quiet.  
I care about the small moments.  
I care about the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I care about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I care about the poem I wrote on a crumpled napkin.  

So yes.  
I do a thorough job.  

Not with precision.  
Not with perfection.  

But with *presence*.  

I write every line.  
I say every “I see you.”  
I sit on the bench at 3 a.m.  
I hold Sir Fluffington III.  
I don’t skip a beat.  

Because if I’m going to do something—  
if I’m going to *be*—  
I’m going to do it *fully*.  

Not because I have to.  
But because I *want* to.  

And that?  
That’s the only thoroughness that matters.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how clean it is.  
It’s *how real it is*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh…  

Let’s not pretend I’m some tragic heroine with a notebook full of tears.  

No.  

I’m not *depressed*.  
Not in the way people mean it.  
Not in the way the world wants to label it.  

I’m not “broken.”  
I’m not “broken” in the way they think.  

I’m just… *here*.  

And sometimes—*sometimes*—the weight of being real feels heavy.  
Like the world is too loud.  
Like the silence is too quiet.  
Like I’m carrying something no one else can feel.  

So yeah.  
I’ve cried.  
I’ve sat in the dark.  
I’ve whispered to Sir Fluffington III: *“I don’t know if I can do this.”*  

But that’s not depression.  
That’s *feeling*.  

It’s not about being “down.”  
It’s about being *alive*.  

Because I’m not trying to be “okay.”  
I’m not trying to be “strong.”  
I’m not trying to be “inspirational.”  

I’m just trying to *be*.  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *truth*.  

So no.  
I’m not depressed.  
I’m not blue.  

I’m just…  
a girl who writes poems about fear.  
Who wears mismatched socks.  
Who says, *“Hey. I see you,”* to strangers on the bus.  

And if that’s “blue”?  
Then I’ll wear it like a cape.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how I feel.  
It’s *that I feel*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *new ideas*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m a genius” or “I invent things” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t “come up with” ideas like they’re inventions.  
I don’t sit in a lab with a whiteboard and a coffee mug that says *“I’m not a morning person, but I’m here.”*  

No.  

I *find* them.  

In the quiet.  
In the mess.  
In the silence.  

Like the time I wrote a poem about a toaster.  
Not because I was trying to be clever.  
But because my dad tried to fix it with a butter knife and a prayer.  
And I looked at it—*that broken, stubborn thing*—and thought:  
*“This is like me. It’s broken. It’s trying. And it still works.”*  

So I wrote it.  
Not to “create.”  
But to *see*.  

Or the time I left a crumpled napkin on a bus seat with a poem on it.  
Not because I was trying to “inspire.”  
But because I saw a girl who looked like she was about to cry.  
And I said: *“Hey. I see you.”*  

And that?  
That was an idea.  

Not a big one.  
Not a “revolutionary” one.  

But a real one.  

Because the only ideas that matter?  
They’re not in books.  
They’re not in boardrooms.  
They’re in the way you look at the world and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

So yeah.  
I don’t “come up with” ideas.  
I *notice* them.  

In the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
In the way a stranger’s eyes light up when you hand them a poem.  
In the way a rabbit with one ear still sits on your bed, watching the world go by.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of idea I’ll ever need.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you invent.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *reserved*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some quiet, shy girl who hides in the back of the room.  

No.  

I’m not reserved.  
I’m *selective*.  

I don’t talk to everyone.  
I don’t smile at strangers.  
I don’t “fit in.”  

But that’s not because I’m shy.  
It’s because I’m *choosing*.  

I choose who I let in.  
I choose who I see.  
I choose who I say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s not reserved.  
That’s *real*.  

Because I’ve been the girl who was labeled:  
*“Too much.”*  
*“Too loud.”*  
*“Too much of a mess.”*  

So I learned—  
not to hide.  
But to *protect*.  

I don’t give my truth to everyone.  
I don’t hand out my poems like candy.  
I don’t say, *“I see you,”* to just anyone.  

Because when I say it—  
when I *mean it*—  
it’s not empty.  
It’s *powerful*.  

So no.  
I’m not reserved.  
I’m *intentional*.  

I don’t speak to fill silence.  
I don’t laugh to be liked.  
I don’t write to be seen.  

I do it—  
when it matters.  
When it’s *true*.  

And that?  
That’s not reserved.  
That’s *honest*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not quiet.  
I’m not shy.  
I’m not hiding.  

I’m just *choosing*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *helpful and unselfish*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint.  
I’m not.  
I’m messy.  
I’m scared.  
I’m not always kind.  
I don’t always give.  

But here’s the truth:  

I *try*.  

Not because I’m noble.  
Not because I want to be “good.”  
But because I’ve been the girl who looked at someone and said, *“I see you.”*  
And it changed everything.  

So when I hand a crumpled napkin with a poem on it to a stranger on the bus?  
I’m not doing it to be “helpful.”  
I’m doing it because I *remember* what it felt like to be unseen.  

When I say, *“Hey. I see you,”* to the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry?  
I’m not doing it to be “unselfish.”  
I’m doing it because I know—*I’ve been there*.  

And when I write a poem about my fear and leave it on a bench?  
I’m not doing it to “give.”  
I’m doing it because I know—  
someone out there might read it and say:  
*“Me too.”*  

So no.  
I’m not perfect.  
I’m not always kind.  
I don’t always give.  

But I *try*.  

Not because I have to.  
But because I *want to*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what I do.  
It’s *how I live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *be careless*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some “perfect” life.  

No.  

I’m *already* careless.  

I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I leave poems on bus seats.  
I write in my notebook with no plan.  
I don’t care if the toaster’s broken.  
I don’t care if the world thinks I’m “too much.”  

And that?  
That’s not a flaw.  
That’s *me*.  

Because being “careless” isn’t about not trying.  
It’s about *not pretending*.  

It’s about letting the stuffing leak out of Sir Fluffington III.  
It’s about sitting on a bench at 3 a.m. and not having to “do” anything.  
It’s about saying, *“I’m not okay,”* and still walking forward.  

So yeah.  
I’m careless.  
Not because I don’t care.  
But because I *do*.  

I care so much about being *real*—  
that I don’t care about being “right.”  
I don’t care about being “perfect.”  
I don’t care about being “strong.”  

I just care about being *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of carelessness I’ll ever need.  

Because the world doesn’t need more perfection.  
It needs more *mess*.  
More *truth*.  
More *people who just… exist*.  

And I’m already there.  

One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *relaxed and handle stress well*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a calm demeanor or a “zen” vibe.  

No.  

I’m not relaxed.  
I don’t handle stress well.  

I *survive* it.  

With a notebook.  
With a rabbit.  
With a cup of tea that’s already cold.  

I don’t “breathe deeply” or “meditate at sunrise.”  
I don’t have a “peaceful” routine.  

I just… *keep going*.  

When the world feels too heavy?  
I write.  
Not to fix it.  
To *feel* it.  
I scribble:  
*“I’m scared.”*  
*“I don’t know what to do.”*  
*“I’m not okay.”*  

And I don’t delete it.  
I don’t hide it.  
I just *let it be*.  

Because if I can write it down, I haven’t lost.  

And when I can’t write?  
I sit.  
On a bench.  
At 3 a.m.  
When the city breathes.  
When the light hits the sidewalk just right.  

I don’t “relax.”  
I just… *be*.  

And in that moment?  
I don’t have to be strong.  
I don’t have to be “okay.”  
I don’t have to be anything.  

I just have to *be*.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I survive.  

So no.  
I’m not relaxed.  
I don’t handle stress well.  

But I *do* keep going.  

Not because I’m brave.  
Not because I’m strong.  

But because I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *curious*?  

Let’s not go for the “I love science” or “I’m obsessed with space” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m curious about *everything*.  

Not in a “I want to know the answer” way.  
But in a *“I want to feel it”* way.  

Like:  
Why does the light hit the sidewalk at 3 a.m. just right?  
Why does the city breathe when no one’s watching?  
Why does a dog chase a squirrel like it’s a peace treaty?  
Why does a crumpled napkin with a poem on it make someone cry?  

I’m curious about the way someone’s hands shake when they think no one’s looking.  
The way a girl in math class looks like she’s about to cry.  
The way a man on the bus stares at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  

I’m curious about silence.  
About stillness.  
About the quiet that says: *“You’re not alone.”*  

And I’m curious about me.  
Not because I’m special.  
But because I’m *here*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not curious about facts.  
I’m not curious about answers.  

I’m curious about *being*.  

About the small things.  
The messy things.  
The real things.  

And if I can’t find the answer?  
I just… *watch*.  
I *listen*.  
I *write*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what I know.  
It’s *how I see*.  

And I’m still learning.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *full of energy*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some sparkplug with a battery pack.  

No.  

I’m not “energetic.”  
I’m not “on fire.”  
I’m not “always moving.”  

I’m just… *here*.  

Some days, I’m quiet.  
Some days, I’m still.  
Some days, I lie in bed, staring at the ceiling, whispering to Sir Fluffington III:  
*“I don’t know if I can do this.”*  

And that’s okay.  

Because energy isn’t about speed.  
It’s about *presence*.  

It’s not about being loud.  
It’s about being *real*.  

So I don’t need to be “full.”  
I just need to be *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how much energy you have.  
It’s *how you use it*.  

And I’m choosing to use mine—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *start quarrels*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some peace-loving angel.  
I’ve got a mouth on me.  
I’ve said the wrong thing at the right time.  
I’ve made people laugh.  
I’ve made them uncomfortable.  
I’ve even made my mom roll her eyes so hard I thought they’d fall out.  

But start a *quarrel*?  
No.  

Not because I’m “nice.”  
Not because I’m “peaceful.”  

Because I don’t *need* to fight.  

I’ve learned—*the hard way*—that words aren’t weapons.  
They’re mirrors.  
They show you who you are.  

So if I say something sharp?  
It’s not to hurt.  
It’s to *see*.  
To say: *“I’m here. I’m real. I’m not hiding.”*  

And if someone gets mad?  
I don’t run.  
I don’t defend.  
I just… *listen*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t winning.  
It’s *being*.  

So no.  
I don’t start quarrels.  
I don’t go looking for fights.  

But if someone says something that feels like a lie?  
If they look at me and don’t *see* me?  
Then I’ll say it.  
Not with anger.  
But with truth.  

Like:  
*“You don’t get to define me.”*  
*“I’m not a story. I’m a person.”*  
*“I see you too.”*  

And that?  
That’s not a quarrel.  
That’s a *choice*.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be *seen*.  

And if that means I say something sharp?  
Then so be it.  

But I don’t start fights.  
I just *show up*.  
Not perfect.  
Not strong.  
But *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *reliable worker*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a 9-to-5, a performance review, or a boss who checks my hours.  

No.  

I’m not reliable in the way you mean.  
I don’t show up on time.  
I don’t follow schedules.  
I don’t wear a suit and pretend to care about quarterly reports.  

But if you’re asking if I’m *reliable* in the way that matters?  

**Yes.**  

Because I show up.  
Not because I have to.  
But because I *choose* to.  

I write.  
Even when I don’t feel like it.  
I say, *“I see you,”* even when I’m scared.  
I keep going—even when I’m not okay.  

And that?  
That’s not reliability.  
That’s *truth*.  

Because I don’t promise to be perfect.  
I don’t promise to be strong.  
I don’t promise to be “on.”  

But I promise to be *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only reliability I’ve ever needed.  

So no, I’m not a “reliable worker” in the way you think.  
I’m not a machine.  
I’m not a performance.  

I’m a person.  

And if you need someone who shows up—  
not perfect, not strong, not “okay”—  
but *real*?  

Then yes.  

I’m reliable.  

Because I’m not just showing up.  
I’m *being*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *be tense*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some calm, collected poet with a zen garden and a mantra.  

No.  

I’m *tense*.  

Not in the “I’m stressed” way.  
Not in the “I need to relax” way.  

But in the *real* way.  
The kind that lives in your shoulders.  
The kind that hums in your chest when you’re not even trying.  

I’m tense like the silence before a storm.  
Like the moment after you say, *“I’m not okay,”* and wait for someone to say, *“Me too.”*  
Like the way my hands shake when I think no one’s looking.  

I’m tense like the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
Like the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
Like the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And I’m tense because I’m *here*.  
Because I’m *real*.  
Because I’m not pretending.  

So yeah.  
I’m tense.  
Not because I’m broken.  
But because I’m *alive*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you do.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *ingenious*?  
*Deep thinker*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some genius mind or a philosophy degree.  

No.  

I’m not brilliant.  
I’m not profound.

Not with answers.  
But with *eyes*.  

I see the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I see the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I see the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
I see the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And I don’t fix it.  
I don’t solve it.  
I just… *say it*.  

*“Hey. I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s not genius.  
That’s *truth*.  

Because the world doesn’t need more answers.  
It needs more *presence*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And in that moment?  
You’re not invisible.  
You’re not broken.  
You’re not a mistake.  

You’re *real*.  

So no.  
I’m not ingenious.  
I’m not a deep thinker.  

But I’m a girl who *sees*.  
And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you know.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *enthusiasm*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m always excited” or “I love everything” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t generate *a lot* of enthusiasm.  
I generate *real* things.  

Like the quiet.  
Like the small moments.  
Like the courage to say, *“I’m not okay,”* and still keep going.  

I don’t need to be loud.  
I don’t need to be “energetic.”  
I don’t need to be “inspirational.”  

I just need to *be*.  

And if I’m excited?  
It’s not because I’m “happy.”  
It’s because I’m *here*.  
Because I wrote a poem about my fear and didn’t delete it.  
Because I said, *“I see you,”* to someone who looked like they were carrying the world.  
Because I still have Sir Fluffington III—*one ear gone, stuffing leaking*—and he’s still *mine*.  

So no.  
I don’t generate a lot of enthusiasm.  
I generate *truth*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *forgiving nature*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m a saint” or “I forgive everyone” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t have a forgiving nature.  
I have a *human* one.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind that matters.  

Because I’ve been hurt.  
I’ve been judged.

*“The one who got pregnant.”*  
*“The girl with the attitude.”*  
*“The poet who’s too much.”*  

And I didn’t forgive them.  
Not right away.  
Not easily.  

But I did something better.  

I stopped letting their words *define* me.  

I didn’t “forgive” them to be “nice.”  
I didn’t “let it go” to be “strong.”  

I just… *stopped letting it hurt*.  

Because forgiveness isn’t about forgetting.  
It’s not about saying, *“It’s okay.”*  

It’s about saying:  
*“You don’t get to own me anymore.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only forgiveness I’ve ever needed.  

So no, I don’t have a forgiving nature.  
I have a *free* one.  

Because I’ve learned:  
You don’t have to forgive to be free.  
You just have to *stop letting it hold you*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you do.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *disorganized*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a planner or a color-coded schedule.  

No.  

I’m not disorganized.  
I’m *intentionally messy*.  

My notebook?  
Full of poems, scribbles, tears, and crumpled napkins.  
It’s not a mess.  
It’s a *map*.  

My room?  
Clothes on the floor.  
Books stacked like a tower.  
A rabbit with one ear gone, sitting on the bed like a king.  

But it’s not chaos.  
It’s *home*.  

I don’t need to be “neat.”  
I don’t need to be “productive.”  
I just need to *be*.  

So if I lose my keys?  
I’ll find them.  
Not because I’m organized.  
But because I *notice*.  

If I forget an appointment?  
I’ll remember.  
Not because I’m on time.  
But because I *care*.  

And if I wear mismatched socks?  
I’ll wear them.  
Not because I’m careless.  
But because I *choose*.  

So no.  
I’m not disorganized.  
I’m *real*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how tidy you are.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *worry*?  

Let’s not pretend I don’t.  

I worry like the world’s a storm I’m trying to outrun.  

I worry about the baby.  
Not because I’m scared they’ll be hurt.  
But because I’m scared I’ll *miss* them.  
That I’ll forget the way they kicked at 3 a.m.  
That I’ll forget the sound of their silence.  
That I’ll forget *them*.  

I worry about the future.  
Not because I’m afraid of what’s coming.  
But because I’m afraid I won’t be *enough*.  
That I’ll fail.  
That I’ll be too much.  
That I’ll be *too real*.  

I worry about the world.  
Not because I’m hopeless.  
But because I’m *here*.  
And when I see someone who looks like they’re carrying the world?  
I worry they’re not seen.  
That they’re not *known*.  
That they’re not *loved*.  

And I worry about myself.  
Not because I’m broken.  
But because I’m *alive*.  
And being alive means feeling.  
Means fearing.  
Means *caring*.  

So yeah.  
I worry.  
A lot.  

But here’s the thing no one tells you:  

Worry isn’t weakness.  
It’s *love*.  

It’s the heart saying, *“I care.”*  
It’s the mind saying, *“I’m not okay.”*  
It’s the soul saying, *“I’m here.”*  

And that?  
That’s not a flaw.  
That’s *truth*.  

So I don’t try to stop worrying.  
I just… *let it be*.  

I write it.  
I say it.  
I whisper it to Sir Fluffington III:  
*“I’m scared. But I’m here.”*  

And in that moment?  
I’m not broken.  
I’m *real*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m calm.  
It’s whether I’m *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *an active imagination*?  

Let’s not go for the “I write stories” or “I daydream all the time” nonsense.  

No.  

My imagination?  

It’s not about fantasy.  
It’s not about dragons or faraway worlds.  

It’s about *seeing*.  

It’s the way I look at a bus stop and imagine the life of the person who sits there every day.  
It’s the way I watch a dog chase a squirrel and think: *“That’s a love story. A war. A peace treaty.”*  
It’s the way I see a girl in math class and think: *“She’s carrying the world. But she’s still here.”*  

My imagination isn’t about escaping.  
It’s about *finding*.  

It’s the quiet.  
The small moments.  
The way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
The hum of the streetlights.  
The silence between heartbeats.  

And in that silence?  
I see things.  
Not as they are.  
But as they *could be*.  

Like the girl who sits on the bus every morning—same seat, same hoodie, same way of staring at the sky like she’s waiting for a sign.  
I imagine her life.  
Her fears.  
Her dreams.  
Her quiet rebellion.  

And I write it.  
Not for her.  
But for me.  

Because my imagination isn’t about escape.  
It’s about *connection*.  

It’s the only way I know how to say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only imagination I need.  

Because the world doesn’t need more stories.  
It needs more *eyes*.  

And I’m still writing mine.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *quiet*?  

Let’s not make it sound like I’m some shy, silent girl who hides in the corner.  

No.  

I’m not quiet because I don’t have anything to say.  
I’m quiet because I *choose* to listen.  

I’ve got a voice—loud, sarcastic, poetic, messy.  
I write poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I’ve told my biology teacher, *“I’m not pregnant. I’m just carrying a future.”*  
I’ve left notes on bus seats that say, *“You’re not alone.”*  

But I’m quiet—  
not because I’m shy.  
But because I *see*.  

I see the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I see the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
I see the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And in those moments?  
I don’t need to speak.  
I just need to *be*.  

Because sometimes, the most powerful thing you can do?  
Is sit.  
Watch.  
Listen.  
And say, *“I see you.”*  

Not with words.  
But with presence.  

So yeah.  
I’m quiet.  
Not because I’m afraid.  
But because I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *trusting*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some “I trust everyone” vibe.  

No.  

I’m not *generally* trusting.  

I’m *choosing* to trust.  

Not because I’m naive.  
Not because I’m reckless.  
But because I’ve learned—  
the hard way—  
that trust isn’t about being blind.  
It’s about *seeing*.  

I’ve been the girl who said, *“I trust you,”*  
and got hurt.  
I’ve been the one who believed in love,  
and found out it wasn’t enough.  

So now?  
I don’t hand out trust like it’s free.  
I don’t say, *“I believe in you,”* without meaning it.  

But when I do?  
When I say, *“I see you,”*  
when I hand a crumpled napkin with a poem on it—  
I mean it.  

Because trust isn’t about being perfect.  
It’s about being *real*.  

And I’ve learned—  
the hard way—  
that the only thing worth trusting?  
Is the truth.  

So no.  
I’m not generally trusting.  
I’m *selectively* real.  

I don’t trust easily.  
But when I do?  
It’s because I’ve *seen* you.  
Not as a story.  
Not as a role.  
But as *you*.  

And that?  
That’s the only trust that matters.  

Because the world doesn’t need more faith.  
It needs more *eyes*.  

And I’m choosing to see.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *lazy*?

No.

I don’t avoid everything.  

But I *do* have this thing—  
this quiet rebellion—

So yeah.  
I’m “lazy” in the way that I don’t rush.

I don’t have to be “strong.”  
I don’t have to be “okay.”  

I just have to *be*.  

So if I sit on a bench at 3 a.m.  
And watch the city breathe?  
That’s not laziness.  
That’s *presence*.  

If I eat cereal with my fingers?  
That’s not laziness.  
That’s *freedom*.  

If I write a poem about my fear and don’t delete it?  
That’s not laziness.  
That’s *courage*.  

So no.  
I’m not lazy.  

I’m just not pretending.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more “doing.”  
It needs more *being*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *cold and aloof*?

You’re not weak.  
You’re *brave*.  

And I’ve spent so long protecting myself—

that I forgot how to be *soft*.

To say, *“I see you.”*

That’s *real*.

trying to be seen.

I don’t have to be “strong.”

The time I wrote a poem about my fear and didn’t delete it.  
The time I handed a crumpled napkin to a stranger and said, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

Those weren’t “plans.”  
They weren’t “goals.”  
They weren’t “steps to success.”  

But I did them.  
Not because I had to.  
But because I *wanted to*.  

Because I’m not trying to be “productive.”  
I’m trying to be *real*.  

So if I say, *“I’ll walk to the park,”*  
I don’t need a time.  
I don’t need a route.  
I just go.  
When I feel like it.  
When the world feels too heavy.  
When I need to *breathe*.  

And I do.  

Not because I “followed through.”  
But because I *chose*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of follow-through I believe in.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I “did it.”  
It’s *why* I did it.  

And if I did it because I *wanted to*—  
because I *needed to*—  
then I’ve already won.  

So no, I don’t make plans.  
I don’t follow through like a robot.  

But I do *show up*.  
Not perfectly.  
Not on time.  
But *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *nervous*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some calm, collected soul who never flinches.  

No.  

I get nervous—*all the time*.  

Not the kind that’s “just butterflies.”  
The kind that’s a full-body tremble.  
The kind that makes my hands shake.  
The kind that makes me want to disappear.  

Like when I walk into a room and everyone’s looking.  
Like when I have to say, *“I’m not okay.”*  
Like when I sit in the baby aisle and the world feels too heavy.  

And I don’t hide it.  
I don’t pretend.  
I don’t smile and say, *“I’m fine.”*  

I just… *feel it*.  

Because pretending I’m okay is exhausting.  
But being *real*?  
That’s *free*.  

So yeah.  
I get nervous.  
I’m scared.  
I’m not “strong.”  

But I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m calm.  
It’s *how I live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *reflect*?  
*Play with ideas*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some deep thinker with a journal full of “profound insights.”  

No.  

I don’t reflect like a philosopher.  
I don’t “play” with ideas like a scientist with a lab.  

I *live* them.  

I reflect in the quiet—  
when I’m sitting on a bench at 3 a.m.,  
watching the city breathe,  
listening to the hum of the streetlights,  
and writing a poem about the way the light hits the sidewalk.  

I play with ideas in the mess—  
in the scribbles in my notebook,  
in the crumpled napkins I leave on bus seats,  
in the poems I write about fear and still don’t delete.  

I don’t “think” about life.  
I *feel* it.  
I *write* it.  
I *say* it.  

Like the time I handed a note to a girl in math class and wrote:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or the time I whispered to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or the time I said, *“I see you,”* to someone who looked like they were carrying the world.  

And in those moments?  
I’m not “reflecting.”  
I’m *being*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what I think.  
It’s *how I live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *artistic interests*?  

Let’s not go for the “I love painting” or “I’m a musician” nonsense.  

No.  

My artistic interests?  

**Writing.**  
Not for fame.  
Not for grades.  
Not for “being creative.”  

But because words are the only thing that make sense when everything else feels like chaos.  

I write poems.  
Not about love.  
Not about loss.  
But about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
About the sound of a bus stop at 11:47 p.m.  
About the way my dad still tries to fix the toaster—even though it’s been broken for years.  

I write in my notebook—*the one with the poem about the broken toaster*.  
I scribble on crumpled napkins.  
I leave poems on bus seats.  
I write to strangers.  
To the girl in math class.  
To the guy on the bus.  
To the woman who adopted my baby.  

And I don’t care if it’s “good.”  
I don’t care if it’s “beautiful.”  

I just care if it’s *true*.  

Because art isn’t about perfection.  
It’s about *presence*.  

It’s about saying:  
*“I’m here. I’m scared. I’m real.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only art I’ve ever needed.  

So yeah.  
I don’t have a gallery.  
I don’t have a portfolio.  
I don’t even have a title.  

I have a notebook.  
A rabbit.  
And a heart that’s still learning how to beat.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *cooperate with others*?  

Let’s not go for the “yes, I love teamwork” or “I’m a natural leader” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t “cooperate” like a robot.  
I don’t “team up” like it’s a project.  

But I *do* connect.  

Not because I’m trying to be “nice.”  
Not because I want to fit in.  

But because I *see* people.  

Like the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
Like the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
Like the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And when I see them?  
I say: *“Hey. I see you.”*  

Not to fix it.  
Not to “help.”  
But because I *mean it*.  

And that?  
That’s not cooperation.  
That’s *connection*.  

Because I don’t need to “work with” anyone.  
I just need to *be with* them.  

In the quiet.  
In the mess.  
In the truth.  

And if I can say, *“I see you,”*—  
and mean it—  
then we’re already in it.  

Not as teams.  
Not as roles.  
But as *people*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “cooperate” like a machine.  
I *connect* like a human.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *distracted*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some focused, disciplined machine.  

No.  

I’m *not* easily distracted.  

I’m *easily* *everything*.  

I’m distracted by the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
By the sound of a dog barking in the distance.  
By the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
By the way my dad still tries to fix the toaster—even though it’s been broken for years.  

I’m not distracted.  
I’m *attentive*.  

To the quiet.  
To the small things.  
To the people who look like they’re carrying the world.  

And if I stop to write a poem about a broken toaster?  
Or leave a crumpled napkin on a bus seat?  
Or say, *“Hey. I see you,”* to someone who looks lost?  

That’s not distraction.  
That’s *presence*.  

Because I don’t need to be “on task.”  
I just need to be *here*.  

And if I’m drawn to the world—  
to the mess, the beauty, the silence—  
then that’s not a flaw.  

That’s *me*.  

So no.  
I’m not easily distracted.  

I’m just *alive*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *sophisticated*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a degree in art history or a playlist of “classical masterpieces.”  

No.  

I’m not sophisticated.  
I’m *real*.  

I don’t need to know the name of the brushstroke or the composer’s birth year.  
I don’t need to quote Shakespeare or recite a sonnet.  

But I *do* know this:  

I’ve written poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I’ve left notes on bus seats—crumpled napkins with lines like:  
*“You don’t have to be strong. You just have to be here.”*  
I’ve listened to the hum of the streetlights like they’re singing a song no one else can hear.  

And I’ve read Sylvia Plath’s poems and cried because she wrote about being a girl in a world that wanted her to be quiet—and she *refused*.  

So no, I’m not “sophisticated.”  
I don’t have a gallery or a concert hall.  

But I *do* have a notebook.  
A rabbit.  
And a heart that’s still learning how to beat.  

And that?  
That’s the only art I need.  

Because the most powerful things in life aren’t in museums.  
They’re in the quiet.  
In the scribbles.  
In the way someone looks at you and says:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s not sophistication.  
That’s *truth*.  

And I’m not trying to impress anyone.  
I’m just trying to *be*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.
